issue.title: Use application/ld+json as Content-Type for the Omeka S API
issue.body:
Currently the Content-Type of the of the API response is `application/json; charset=utf-8` (like https://www.goudatijdmachine.nl/omeka/api/items/37476 and also the context https://www.goudatijdmachine.nl/omeka/api-context).

![image](https://github.com/omeka/omeka-s/assets/101820/44d9d469-16ef-4718-95a0-0581ea51c0a9)

The Omeka S API outputs a more specific kind of JSON: JSON-LD. So the content-type of these responses from the Omeka S API should reflect this and use the Content-Type `application/ld+json; charset=utf-8` (see also https://www.w3.org/TR/json-ld11/).

I stumbled on this issue while using the (standards adhering) tool https://sketch.zazuko.com/ - I pasted the output of the Omeka S API into this tool and it showed the (correct) error: 
```
Error: 
Failed to load remote context https://www.goudatijdmachine.nl/omeka/api-context: 
Unsupported JSON-LD media type application/json
```

issue.title: Performance issues with advanced search queries
issue.body: Running an advanced search query with more than 3 `OR` clauses takes over 75s to complete even with dedicated, high-performance hardware. Additional clauses increase the query time exponentially. I've tested on small installations with few items and populated metadata fields, but it doesn't make much difference. We're trying use this to search for a handful of metadata keywords, which I'd imagine is a relatively common use case.

comment.body:
Thanks, this is very helpful feedback.

I'll update when we've moved on this... probably a merge of that branch, though we'll probably squash it or otherwise clean it up a little before then.

pull_request.title: Fix/index public
pull_request.body: For performance issue, there is the index on is_public, even if it is a boolean.

issue.title: Performance issues with advanced search queries
issue.body: Running an advanced search query with more than 3 `OR` clauses takes over 75s to complete even with dedicated, high-performance hardware. Additional clauses increase the query time exponentially. I've tested on small installations with few items and populated metadata fields, but it doesn't make much difference. We're trying use this to search for a handful of metadata keywords, which I'd imagine is a relatively common use case.

comment.body: I ran some more tests and everything works well, within reasonable limits. Thanks again for working on this, I support it being merged

payload.description: Omeka S is a web publication system for universities, galleries, libraries, archives, and museums. It consists of a local network of independently curated exhibits sharing a collaboratively built pool of items, media, and their metadata.

issue.title: Performance/mariadb
issue.body: On bases with many linked resources, the search is very slow on mariadb. So this is a fix, just a composite index in fact, that allows to search instantly for the most common queris (https://github.com/omeka/omeka-s/blob/develop/application/src/Api/Adapter/AbstractResourceEntityAdapter.php#L281-L294).

comment.body: For is_public, the order is important, because there is no index on is_public and when there is a composite index, the first index can be used as a single index (and the first with the second one, etc.). So the first thing is to have an index on it, so see the pr #2105 if you don't like composite index. It will resolve most of this issue too.

issue.title: Performance/mariadb
issue.body: On bases with many linked resources, the search is very slow on mariadb. So this is a fix, just a composite index in fact, that allows to search instantly for the most common queris (https://github.com/omeka/omeka-s/blob/develop/application/src/Api/Adapter/AbstractResourceEntityAdapter.php#L281-L294).

comment.body: Yes, i tested on mysql (prod server on huma-num.fr) and mariadb (test server).

issue.title: Performance issues with advanced search queries
issue.body: Running an advanced search query with more than 3 `OR` clauses takes over 75s to complete even with dedicated, high-performance hardware. Additional clauses increase the query time exponentially. I've tested on small installations with few items and populated metadata fields, but it doesn't make much difference. We're trying use this to search for a handful of metadata keywords, which I'd imagine is a relatively common use case.

comment.body: Just from initial tinkering, this looks great – huge improvement. I'll test it out more rigorously and report back.
